instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PP1V2_S3: What is PP1V2_S3? PP1V2_S3 is a 1.2v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.PP1V8_S3: What is PP1V8_S3? The PP1V8_S3 signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides a voltage of 1.8 volts during the S3 power state. The S3 state, often referred to as "suspend to RAM," is a low-power mode where the computer saves the session's state to RAM, allowing for quicker wake-up times compared to a full shutdown..
definitions.PP1V05_SUS: What is PP1V05_SUS? The PP1V05_SUS signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that supplies 1.05 volts, typically used in a suspended (SUS) state of the laptop. This state is a low-power mode where essential system functions are maintained, but the majority of the system is powered down..
definitions.PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT: What is PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT? Power rail for RAM. .
definitions.PP3V3S3_EN: What is PP3V3S3_EN? PP3V3S3_EN is a typo of P3V3S3_EN, which is a signal that turns on the PP3V3_S3 power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pulsing rails
threads.message:
Hey there :-)

I got another <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with some problems. It is in S5 State and nearly all other power rails are pulsing:
Lokked like someone else already worked on this board before. But no signs of liquid damage, all probe points look very clean.
The Board is taking 24mA - sometimes dropping to 14mA.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   
[TABLE]
[TR]
[TD][LEFT][B]Rail[/B][/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT][B]Voltage[/B][/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT][B]Resistance to Ground[/B][/LEFT][/TD]
[/TR]
[TR]
[TD][LEFT]<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]8.6V[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT][/LEFT][/TD]
[/TR]
[TR]
[TD][LEFT]<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]3.41V[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT][/LEFT][/TD]
[/TR]
[TR]
[TD][LEFT]<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]5.01V[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT][/LEFT][/TD]
[/TR]
[TR]
[TD][LEFT]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]3.33V[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT][/LEFT][/TD]
[/TR]
[TR]
[TD][LEFT]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]pulsing[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]3.53kO[/LEFT][/TD]
[/TR]
[TR]
[TD][LEFT]<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]pulsing[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]40kO[/LEFT][/TD]
[/TR]
[TR]
[TD][LEFT]<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]pulsing[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]2.05kO[/LEFT][/TD]
[/TR]
[TR]
[TD][LEFT]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]3.33V[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT][/LEFT][/TD]
[/TR]
[TR]
[TD][LEFT]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]pulsing[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]28.7kO[/LEFT][/TD]
[/TR]
[TR]
[TD][LEFT]<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]3.41V[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT][/LEFT][/TD]
[/TR]
[TR]
[TD][LEFT]<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]3.33V[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT][/LEFT][/TD]
[/TR]
[TR]
[TD][LEFT]<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]pulsing[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]39.3kO[/LEFT][/TD]
[/TR]
[TR]
[TD][LEFT]<SIGNAL>PP3V3S3_EN</SIGNAL>[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]pulsing[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]37kO[/LEFT][/TD]
[/TR]
[TR]
[TD][LEFT]<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]pulsing[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]36.8kO[/LEFT][/TD]
[/TR]
[TR]
[TD][LEFT]<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]pulsing[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]245kO[/LEFT][/TD]
[/TR]
[TR]
[TD][LEFT]<SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL>[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]3.29V[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT][/LEFT][/TD]
[/TR]
[TR]
[TD][LEFT]<SIGNAL>PP1V05_SUS</SIGNAL>[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]1.06V[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT][/LEFT][/TD]
[/TR]
[TR]
[TD][LEFT]<SIGNAL>CPU_VCCST_PWRGD</SIGNAL>[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]pulsing[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT][/LEFT][/TD]
[/TR]
[TR]
[TD][LEFT]<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]3.41V[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT][/LEFT][/TD]
[/TR]
[TR]
[TD][LEFT]<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]pulsing[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]250kO[/LEFT][/TD]
[/TR]
[TR]
[TD][LEFT]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]pulsing[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]30kO[/LEFT][/TD]
[/TR]
[TR]
[TD][LEFT]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4SW_SNS</SIGNAL>[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]pulsing[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]31kO[/LEFT][/TD]
[/TR]
[TR]
[TD][LEFT]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0SW_SSD</SIGNAL>[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]pulsing[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]50kO[/LEFT][/TD]
[/TR]
[TR]
[TD][LEFT]<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4_TBTAPWR</SIGNAL>[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]pulsing[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]36kO[/LEFT][/TD]
[/TR]
[TR]
[TD][LEFT]<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S3</SIGNAL>[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]pulsing[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]1.5kO[/LEFT][/TD]
[/TR]
[TR]
[TD][LEFT]<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL>[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]pulsing[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]0.5kO[/LEFT][/TD]
[/TR]
[TR]
[TD][LEFT]<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL>[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]pulsing[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]4kO[/LEFT][/TD]
[/TR]
[TR]
[TD][LEFT]<SIGNAL>PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL>[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]pulsing[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]0.25kO[/LEFT][/TD]
[/TR]
[TR]
[TD][LEFT]<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL>[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]pulsing[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]0.25kO[/LEFT][/TD]
[/TR]
[TR]
[TD][LEFT]<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0SW_PCH_HSIO</SIGNAL>[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]pulsing[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]0.5kO[/LEFT][/TD]
[/TR]
[TR]
[TD][LEFT]<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]pulsing[/LEFT][/TD]
[TD][LEFT]14O[/LEFT][/TD]
[/TR]
[/TABLE]

When i remove <CHIP>U8005</CHIP> I got a steady fanspin and stable rails.
What I already tried: 

-reballing SMC,
-flash new BIOS
-new <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> from donor
-replace <CHIP>U8005</CHIP>

Bes regards 
DudiPupan

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pulsing rails
threads.message: With SMC bypass I get pulsing short fan spins.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pulsing rails
threads.message: Check for pulse at pin 3/<CHIP>U1950</CHIP>, <SIGNAL>CPU_VR_READY</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pulsing rails
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pulsing rails
threads.message:
Looks like PCH issue then.
Heat it for test...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pulsing rails
